Console Overview Basic Components Logging in Accessing the Administrator Console During Domain Maintenance Inactivity Timeout Logging Out Saving Data Navigating Between Pages and Tabs Terminology Troubleshooting Standard Error Messages Using the Administrator Interface The Five9 contact center is cloud-based software provided as a service for creating and managing contact center operations. As the Five9 Administrator Console gains functionality, we will add new features to this guide. Currently, you must use both the Administrator Console and Five9 Java Administrator applications to fully administer your Five9 Contact Center. Admin Console is the new administrator tool for Five9. As part of this new tool, we are introducing new processes for the administrator to manage the contact center. The Admin Console introduces detailed permissions that enable the administrator to create permission sets for users which enable them to have specific functions, such as create, edit, delete, or update for the different objects in your contact center (see Permissions and Permission Sets). These detailed permissions replace the Java Administrator application permissions that enabled full access to managed objects. Within Admin Console, Java Administrator application permissions are not honored. This means that if you have permission to manage campaigns in the Five9 Java Administrator application, you

contact center (see Permissions and Permission Sets). These detailed permissions replace the Java Administrator application permissions that enabled full access to managed objects. Within Admin Console, Java Administrator application permissions are not honored. This means that if you have permission to manage campaigns in the Five9 Java Administrator application, you may not be able to manage campaigns in Admin Console. Admin Console is zero trust; until an administrator provides you permission you cannot perform any actions. To access the Admin Console, a user must be granted access to use a Five9 application, like Admin Console, ADP, Supervisor, and others. Applications will start to replace the Java Administrator application roles that provided access to ADP, Supervisor, and other applications. About the Administrator Console Multiple Administrators 17 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Multiple Administrators Admin Console supports multiple administrators working concurrently. This is different behavior than the Five9 Java Administrator application where records lock when an administrator opened the item in a window. Important: Use caution when multiple admin users are updating the same object within Admin Console. If two users open the same record simultaneously, changes saved by the first user will be overwritten by the second user. Administrator Console Support

Administrator Console Support Limitations The following are current support limitations for Admin Console. These will be addressed in subsequent updates to Administrator Console. l Duplicating users is not available for a User Profile. l Reason code restriction is controlled availability in Agent (ADP/ADT) applications. l Usage of manager of an agent group is not supported in Supervisor plus application. l Five9 Administrator Console supports only one active session (one user/one domain) at a time in a browser. To create an additional session with another user ID on the same workstation, use a different browser or a private/incognito window. l The Five9 Admin Console does not currently support whitelist IP addresses; When using Trusted IP address, the Admin Console will bypass these IPs and any IP address can get in. l The Five9 for Service Cloud Voice BYOT adapter enables you to integrate Five9 telephony with Salesforce Omni-Channel. About the Administrator Console Administrator Console Overview 18 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Administrator Console Overview Once you sign in, you are directed to the Admin Console interface. The Five9 Admin Console determines the visibility of menu items based on your permissions. The Five9 Admin Console workspace is specific to the options available. The figure below offers some basic controls for navigation. 1 Sidebar - Displays the areas that you are allowed to view or manage. 2 Navigation Menu - Displays links that enable you to view or manage the current area. 3 Workspace - Displays the selected navigation menu item. 4 Refresh the current view. 5 Table Layout Options to refine your view. 6 Filter the current view. 7 Export this listing page <where applicable>. 8 Create new item <specific to workspace>. Logging in To log into your Five9 account, follow these steps: 1 Enter the URL that applies to your location. o US domains: https://admin.us.five9.net/ o Canadian domains: https://admin.ca.five9.net/ o UK domains: https://admin.uk.five9.net/ About the Administrator Console Logging in 20 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide o European domains: https://admin.eu.five9.net/ 2 Enter your credentials (username and password) when prompted. Note: Upon logging into the Admin Console, a message appears stating, "Your password has expired. You must log in again and reset your password on the main portal." A race condition is preventing all systems from being updated for the password reset. You may be prompted to reset your password again. To address this condition, click Reset Password (your password does not

password has expired. You must log in again and reset your password on the main portal." A race condition is preventing all systems from being updated for the password reset. You may be prompted to reset your password again. To address this condition, click Reset Password (your password does not need to be reset again, as it was reset correctly), and then return to the Admin Console login page. The following message indicates that you may have valid credentials for Five9 access, but may not be enabled for the region that you selected. In this case, ensure that you select the region that indicates your contact center locale. About the Administrator Console Accessing the Administrator Console During Domain Maintenance 21 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Accessing the Administrator Console During Domain Maintenance If your company uses the Five9 Managed Geographic Redundancy (MGR) feature, and you are logged into your Five9 console when maintenance is required or an outage occurs, your Five9 server is moved to a backup data center. Administrators, supervisors, and agents receive notices about the status of server changes during the switchover process. MGR messages do not currently show in the Five9 Admin Console. Managing Maintenance Moves During

console when maintenance is required or an outage occurs, your Five9 server is moved to a backup data center. Administrators, supervisors, and agents receive notices about the status of server changes during the switchover process. MGR messages do not currently show in the Five9 Admin Console. Managing Maintenance Moves During a major service disruption, Five9 may move your application server to a backup data center until the issue is resolved. Five9 MGR is designed to mitigate major service disruptions that might otherwise result in extended downtime for the Five9 Virtual Contact Center platform. Domains are typically operational in the backup data center within 15 minutes. Once service is restored in the primary domain, Five9 returns affected domains to their primary data center. Inactivity Timeout The Five9 Administrator Console will timeout after 30 minutes of inactivity. For the purpose of timeout, activity is any action that interacts with the Five9 system, such as saving data, API calls, or loading new data. 30 minutes of inactivity requires you to refresh authentication. Example: You open several pages, such as Users, Campaigns, and Permissions. Loading these list-display tables pulls data from the Five9 system. No system interaction is involved as you navigate these pages;

Note About the Administrator Console Logging Out 22 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Adding a new item, such as enabling a permission for a user, interacts with the Five9 system and is activity for timeout purposes. Logging Out When you are done using the Administrator Console it is recommended to log out, and not just close the browser window. In the bottom left corner is an icon with your initials on it. Select your initials icon to logout. Saving Data Saving data within the Administrator Console happens automatically as you navigate away from pages. There are some instance where a workspace has only a single page. In those cases use the Save icon in the top right corner, otherwise select the Done action to save your work and return to the previous page. Many changes are immediate and saved to the Five9 system once they

are some instance where a workspace has only a single page. In those cases use the Save icon in the top right corner, otherwise select the Done action to save your work and return to the previous page. Many changes are immediate and saved to the Five9 system once they are input or selected, when this happens there is a spinning wheel indication that will pause the Administrator Console until the save action complete. The indication may be at the tab level or at the individual element level. 1 Saving Tab Contents 2 Saving Row Changes For pages that have more than one page there is a Done button in the top right corner that will do two things: 1 Save the current details, and 2 Navigate back to the previous page (in most cases this is a listing page). About the Administrator Console Navigating Between Pages and Tabs 23 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Important: If you create an new object with the same name and description as an existing object, the Five9 Administrator Console will present the existing object upon save. A second, or duplicate, instance of that object will not be created. Navigating Between Pages and Tabs

Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Important: If you create an new object with the same name and description as an existing object, the Five9 Administrator Console will present the existing object upon save. A second, or duplicate, instance of that object will not be created. Navigating Between Pages and Tabs Data is automatically saved when you navigate between tabs. Some pages require that all tabs are completed before saving is allowed. You may see an Apply option as well as a Done button. To check your progress on all tabs, select Apply. Another navigation area to be aware of is the Go Back icon, when you click this button the system checks to see if the current page contents have been modified and will prompt a Save, Discard, or Cancel dialog to allow you to save the data or navigate away without saving. items together based on the areas that they manage. Each workspace is a small application that enables the manipulation of the data for that area. Each page is controlled by a view permission that is granted to the user, and the actions within the pages are controlled by the logic and permissions within those individual workspaces. Users can be grouped by skills, their role in a campaign, or other designation. Only users assigned the agent or supervisor roles may be added to agent groups. Supervisors can be configured to see all skills and all agent groups or only those groups to which they are members. Supervisors can broadcast a message to groups and skills to reach all agents with the definitions in common. Agent groups appear in agent reports. For example, reports can show how effectively supervisors manage the groups by running a report that shows which agent group occupancy is higher (which supervisor is more effective in keeping the agents busy). The Five9 Admin Console enables you to create and populate groups and to identify users within that group as members or managers of that group. Agent Groups Agent Group Details

You can access the ANI Settings page from the Administrator Console homepage card or the Manage Environment icon in the sidebar navigation. Use the Default Settings tab to identify the default ANI settings for your domain. Field Description Default ANI This field is your default ANI for dis- play. Default DID ANI This field is your Direct Inward Dial (DID) ANI. International numbers can contain a maximum of 17 digits, plus prefix. The prefix may be 011 (for a total of 20 digits) or + (for a total of 17 digits plus a + sign) ANI. API access control allows you to manage and control access

your domain. Contact your Five9 representative for early enablement. Overview With API access control, you can create and manage scope-based access control lists, assign machine user credentials, set expiry dates for credentials, and modify and format views of the list. API access control allows you to manage and control access to APIs using access tokens, authorization, and appropriate permissions (scopes). See Configuring API Access Control to configure access. Key Concepts Scopes Scopes are permissions included in access tokens, specifying actions that can be performed on the API. They define specific actions an application can perform, such as creating, updating, viewing, or registering events. Families Families are groupings of related APIs or endpoints that share common access policies or credentials, making it easier to manage access controls efficiently. This organization ensures that applications have the appropriate level of access while maintaining security and order. API Access Control Application Attributes 49 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Example: Family Name: all-apis-access Scope Assignment: users:read This specific scope is assigned to the all-apis-access family, indicating read-only access to user services-related data. Best Practices l Ensure that scopes are correctly assigned to maintain security. l Regularly review and update access controls to reflect changes in

Console • Administrator’s Guide Example: Family Name: all-apis-access Scope Assignment: users:read This specific scope is assigned to the all-apis-access family, indicating read-only access to user services-related data. Best Practices l Ensure that scopes are correctly assigned to maintain security. l Regularly review and update access controls to reflect changes in your API usage. Self-Service Features l View API Applications: Attributes include Application ID, Name, Status, Family, Contact Email, Scopes, Created On, Created By, and Last Modified On. l Create Direct Access Tokens: Generate tokens for API usage. l Manage Machine User Credentials: o Associate machine users with credentials. o Assign roles and permissions. o Set expiry dates for credentials. Application Attributes An application can have attributes such as a unique identifier (appId), name, current status, product family, family type, contact email, associated permissions (scopes), creation date (createdOn), creator (createdBy), and last modification date (lastModifiedOn). l appId: Unique identifier for the application. l name: Name of the application. l status: Current status of the application. l family: Product family of the application. API Access Control Credential Attributes 50 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide l family type: Type of family. l contactEmail: Contact email for the application. l scopes: Permissions associated with

application. l name: Name of the application. l status: Current status of the application. l family: Product family of the application. API Access Control Credential Attributes 50 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide l family type: Type of family. l contactEmail: Contact email for the application. l scopes: Permissions associated with the application. l createdOn: Date the application was created. l createdBy: User who created the application. l lastModifiedOn: Date the application was last modified. Credential Attributes l credentialId: Identifier for the credential; a hash of the consumer key. l consumerKey: Consumer key of the credential. l consumerSecret: Secret for the credential, empty when the family has type CUSTOMER_ANON. l expiresAt: Credential date/time expiration. l issuedAt: Credential issuing date/time. l status: Status of the credential, either ACTIVE or REVOKED. API Access Control Configuring API Access Control 51 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Configuring API Access Control Note: This feature is under controlled availability (CA). You may not see this feature in your domain. Contact your Five9 representative for early enablement. API access control allows you to create and manage scope-based access control lists, assign machine user credentials, set expiry dates for credentials, and modify and format views of the list. Key

controlled availability (CA). You may not see this feature in your domain. Contact your Five9 representative for early enablement. API access control allows you to create and manage scope-based access control lists, assign machine user credentials, set expiry dates for credentials, and modify and format views of the list. Key functionalities for managing credentials include: l Each API can have up to two active credentials. l Credentials are available for copy only once. l Share credentials manually via your preferred method (for example: email). How It Works l Create Access: Set up new access controls; provide necessary details such as name, contact email, and duration. l Select Family: Choose the relevant API family from the list. Families group related APIs or endpoints that share common access policies or credentials. l Assign Scopes: Select the necessary scopes from the available list. Scopes control access to specific functionality within the API family and allow for fine-grained access control, ensuring that only necessary permissions are granted. l Manage Credentials: Assign machine user credentials, set expiry dates, and associate them with specific roles and permissions. During an interaction, they can be used and updated in the IVR and by agents. When configuring dispositions, you can also set the value for call variables that should be stored for reporting purposes when that disposition is used, or when any disposition is used. With call

of contact records. During an interaction, they can be used and updated in the IVR and by agents. When configuring dispositions, you can also set the value for call variables that should be stored for reporting purposes when that disposition is used, or when any disposition is used. With call variables, you can gather more information about each interaction. For example, you can collect error codes generated by IVR and find out how many times a speech input was provided, an account balance retrieved, and customer satisfaction survey results. In addition to U.S currency, all currency variables support the British Pound and Euro currencies. You can use call variables in connectors and IVR scripts to send information, for example, to third-party systems. Optionally, call variables can be stored to use in reports. The variables are organized in groups, similar to classes used in many programming languages. When using a variable, follow this syntax: [Call Variable Group Name].[Call Variable Name] Call.mediatype In reports, you can summarize call variable values across calls to provide the total sale amount per agent or per campaign based on individual sale amounts from each call. In the Variables folder, you can create items variables in predefined

follow this syntax: [Call Variable Group Name].[Call Variable Name] Call.mediatype In reports, you can summarize call variable values across calls to provide the total sale amount per agent or per campaign based on individual sale amounts from each call. In the Variables folder, you can create items variables in predefined variable groups or add custom groups. For example, you can create skill-based groups or groups for Example Call Variables Creating Call Variables 75 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide surveys, sales, error handling to store more information about error codes generated by IVR, and speech recognition events. Transcripts Tab Transcripts Wrap-up Tab Maintenance Notice Notification Campaigns Page Permissions Inbound Campaigns You can access campaigns using the Administrator Console homepage card or left navigation bar. Inbound campaigns receive customer interactions coming from a DNIS according to your rules in the Interactive Voice Response (IVR) script associated with the campaign. With the inbound campaign, you can customie greetings and create scenarios for your interaction routing. The automated routing of customer inquiries sends the interactions to the most appropriate agents: Campaigns Create Inbound Campaigns 87 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide l Sends incoming calls to agents based on availability or skill with custom prompts and hold music. l Creates loops and branches, collect caller information, and use contact data. l Allows callers to leave messages when queue times are long or agents are unavailable. l Forwards calls to a third party when agents are unavailable. l Prioritizes inbound traffic. The campaign must be running to answer inbound calls. If the campaign is not running, the caller hears a busy signal. The answering agent associated with the inbound campaign sees all records with the caller's number that the system found. The first record found displays by default. No records display if

campaign must be running to answer inbound calls. If the campaign is not running, the caller hears a busy signal. The answering agent associated with the inbound campaign sees all records with the caller's number that the system found. The first record found displays by default. No records display if the caller's number isn't in the contact database. Data in Scripts To use contact fields in a script, you must save the script as HTML and edit the HTML code. You can edit the code in a text editor or an HTML editor before importing it into the campaign, or you can edit the code after importing. Recordings and Transcripts Tab The system saves call recordings for campaigns in the agent's user properties using the session ID of the interaction. The session ID displays in call logs, worksheets, and the call segment report. Recordings are limited to one hour. Contact your Five9 representative to increase this limit to up to three hours if your campaign interactions may extend beyond one hour. The recording is a WAV file that contains the agents' conversations during the call sessions. Five9 accounts with five seats has one port dedicated to call recordings; accounts with 10 seats have two recording ports. This means that if 10 agents are in calls, 20% of those calls are being recorded. Note: Contact your Five9 representative to request additional recording ports. Campaign Profiles Page Permissions You create campaign profiles to define the behavior of campaign components and define campaign characteristics. Campaign profiles override campaign defaults such as the default ANI. Campaign profiles can be associated to multiple campaigns to allow those campaigns to function similarly. The campaign uses the properties that you define in the profile. You can create as many profiles as you need, but you can only associate one profile per campaign. Use workflow rules to automatically change profiles for a campaign. Campaign profiles enable you to filter and sort lists of contacts used for customer reference or dialing outbound calls, control pop-up windows in the agent interface, and manage disposition counts. You can create, edit, and delete profiles, based on your permission settings. You access Campaign Profiles from the Administrator Console homepage or the Manage Campaigns icon in sidebar navigation. For detailed options in campaign profile settings, see also Creating Campaign Profiles. For more information about ANI settings, see also Selecting ANI Settings. Populate the General Settings Campaign Profiles Creating Campaign Profiles 109 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide 1 Provide a unique name and intuitive description for the new campaign profile. 2 Initial call priority: Inbound calls have a default priority of 60 on a scale of 1 to 100. Calls with a higher priority (100) are answered first, regardless of their time in a queue. If a campaign uses a profile with a higher priority, calls belonging to that campaign are answered first. For calls from a campaign to be answered before calls from other campaigns, increase the priority by one. 3 Configure the Outbound Settings as desired. a Maximum charge (no decimals): Dollar amount for the maximum long distance charges. The campaign stops automatically when this amount of long distance charges

first. For calls from a campaign to be answered before calls from other campaigns, increase the priority by one. 3 Configure the Outbound Settings as desired. a Maximum charge (no decimals): Dollar amount for the maximum long distance charges. The campaign stops automatically when this amount of long distance charges is reached. A setting of zero means no limit. b Dialing time-out (in seconds): Enables you to configure how long the system waits before an unanswered call is disconnected and logged as No Answer. In other words, this is how long the dialer rings a number. Sometimes this time period is equated to number of rings but it is actually measured in seconds. The default setting is 20 seconds. The dialing time-out allows you to increase the ring time (not the number of rings) in an effort to reach more answering machines or give the called party more time answer. For autodial campaigns it is sometimes beneficial to increase the dialing timeout in an attempt to capture more answering machines. Warning: This setting has a direct effect on how answering machines and no answers are reported. If the timeout is increased, expect to receive more answering machines and fewer no

For autodial campaigns it is sometimes beneficial to increase the dialing timeout in an attempt to capture more answering machines. Warning: This setting has a direct effect on how answering machines and no answers are reported. If the timeout is increased, expect to receive more answering machines and fewer no answer dispositions. More importantly, if your list is producing a lot of unanswered calls, increasing this setting means it takes longer to process the list and potentially increase the agent idle time. Important: Telemarketing regulations in the U.S. require that calls ring for a minimum of 15 seconds. If you are running telemarketing campaigns, do not reduce this setting to less than 15 seconds. c Dialing attempts: The counter for the Number of Attempts counts all dial attempts for phone numbers in a list record, including redials due to disposition settings. Optionally, select Enable All Certificates to allow the system to trust the certificates from all servers. l The system allows connection with all Web servers even if their certificates cannot be found among the imported ones. l The system allows connection with only the Web servers with certificates already in the list or signed by a certificate authority. Testing the Imported Certificates Send test HTTPS requests to the server from a Web browser. If you are successful, your setup is completed. If you see a browser message about the certificate, most likely you need to import it. Removing a Certificate To remove a certificate, select it in the certificates list and click Delete. You will be prompted to confirm the operation. Group Subset Permission Description eventslog events View and search events log View and search the events log. 124 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Connectors Understanding Connectors Connector Parameters URL Strings Parameter Names Connector Examples Creating a Connector Defining Connector Parameters Selecting the Trigger Using Connectors with Social Interactions Connectors Page Permissions Connectors are URLs that automate tasks, such as looking up a customer record or completing a form. Connectors help agents find information or trigger an action in campaigns where connectors are defined. You can search for call variables that contain customer data, and also parameters, such as call length, handle time, wrap-up time, skill transfer, queue time, and hold time. Connectors perform GET or POST tasks on information in contact records. Important: Use secure URLs and the POST method when using parameters containing sensitive data. You can't save connectors with sensitive data using GET calls or non-secure URLs. Call records contain data fields for all parties that handled the call, the associated campaign, contact information, and call disposition. You can substitute this data in the connector URL and execute these APIs

parameters containing sensitive data. You can't save connectors with sensitive data using GET calls or non-secure URLs. Call records contain data fields for all parties that handled the call, the associated campaign, contact information, and call disposition. You can substitute this data in the connector URL and execute these APIs as the agent processes the call. You can access Connectors using the home page card or by selecting Manage Campaigns from the sidebar navigation. Connectors Understanding Connectors 125 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Understanding Connectors Connectors comprise a URL, a script that defines the action taken by the connector (a GET or POST command), some delimiters, and one or more parameters that define the data to retrieve from the URL or post to the target URL, such as a database or third- party tool. The URL, script, and keywords come from your application, form, or tool, not from Five9 applications. Connector Parameters You append connector parameters as a field or constant to a URL. Proper parameter formatting automatically generates URL strings. Best practices for parameters are: l Parameter names are case sensitive. l The string must be in URL format. l Connectors can include one or more parameters and their associated keywords. l Connectors often display a static Web page, knowledge base, or list. Connectors URL Strings 127 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide The Firefox, Chrome, and Internet Explore browsers do not accept mixed content without special configuration. For example, if you combine secure and non-secure URLs, such as in an integration, the connector may not open in the browser. Best practice is to always use secure URLs and/or enable Execute in Browser. You must always use HTTPS to embed connectors for Web agents. Otherwise the connectors do not display. Connectors triggered by a disposition execute in a new browser window on call completion. To prevent their website from displaying in an iframe on another website, many websites (such as google.com) use the x-frame-options:SAMEORIGIN header. To use the Embedded tab in Agent Desktop Plus, connectors must use the embedded URL call. websites (such as google.com) use the x-frame-options:SAMEORIGIN header. To use the Embedded tab in Agent Desktop Plus, connectors must use the embedded URL call. Five9 Administrator Console supports standard HTTP and secure HTTPS protocols. You can use HTTPS for the system disposition connectors. For secure connections, you can use certificates when the external Web server uses a root certificate (unsigned/self- signed public key certificate). You can import CRT files or enable Accept All Certificates. Use this syntax: http://www.domain.com/page.htm?keyWord_1=@parameter_1@&keyWord_2=@par- rameter_2@ domain.com Domain where the URL exists. The URL standard contains a port specification, for example: www.domain.com means http://www.domain.com:80. The default port is generally omitted. Five9 URLs do not use a port other than 80. page.htm Name of the script being called to perform the GET or POST method. Parameter Names The Five9 contact center provides a set of standard parameter names for connectors. Parameters in the connector URL must begin and end with an at sign (@), for example, @Customer.first_name@. You must separate keyword-parameter pairs with an ampersand (&). The type of call data handled by the parameter is identified by its name, see Parameter Types. Parameter names are case sensitive. The Customer data parameters are the contact fields available in your configuration, including the Five9 default fields and any custom fields. For example, if you create a contact field called email_address, the parameter is Customer.email_address. Connectors Selecting the Trigger 135 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Selecting the Trigger These are examples of connector triggers: l Agent accepts or disconnects a call. l Agent selects a contact record. l Agent receives a preview record. l Agent initiates a warm transfer. l Interaction is routed to a Skill Transfer module in an IVR script. l Agent assigns a system disposition. l Agent accepts a chat or email interaction. Click the Trigger tab, and select one of the trigger options. When done, click Save or Apply twice. Call Events Trigger Event Manually Started Agent clicks the Connector button during a call. (Manual Connector button in Current Call tab of Java agent) Manually Started (Allow during Previews) Agent receives a third-party URL while previewing a call. clicks the Connector button during a call. Connectors Selecting the Trigger 136 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Trigger Event On Call Disconnected Call disconnected or the caller hung up. On Preview Agent accepts a preview contact record. On Contact Selection Agent selects a contact to associate a call with by pressing Select Contact Record. On Warm Transfer Initiation Agent starts a Warm Transfer. On Call Dispositioned Agent selects disposition, which clears the live call screen. Select this option and select the disposition options that trigger the connector. Does not apply to Decline Preview Record dispositions. Chat Interaction Events Trigger Event On Accept Agent accepts a chat routed to their station. On Transfer Agent transfers the chat. On Termination Agent ends the chat. On Close (Disposition) Agent sets the disposition for the chat. Select this option and select the disposition options that trigger the connector. Does not apply to Decline Preview Record dispositions. Email Interaction Events Trigger Event On Accept Agent accepts an email routed to

chat. On Termination Agent ends the chat. On Close (Disposition) Agent sets the disposition for the chat. Select this option and select the disposition options that trigger the connector. Does not apply to Decline Preview Record dispositions. Email Interaction Events Trigger Event On Accept Agent accepts an email routed to their station. On Transfer Agent transfers the email. On Close (Disposition) Agent sets the disposition for the email. Select this option and select the disposition options that trigger the connector. Does not apply to Decline Preview Record dispositions. On Email Dispositioned Agent sets a unified disposition for the email. Unified dispositions must be enabled in the SCC Administrator application to use this control or connector will not trigger. Does not apply to Decline Preview Record dispositions. Using Connectors with Social Interactions If you are using Five9 Digital Engagement, you can use connectors to pass

the interaction. On Close (Disposition) Agent sets the disposition for the interaction. Select this option and select the disposition options that trigger the connector. Context Services Context Services Table Examples 172 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Context Services Table Examples This section presents Context Services tables. rows to define regions or business units. The second example defines corporate events, with columns for event type and event flag, and rows that show business units. These examples give you the basic structure of these tables. Holidays Table by Line of Business (LOB) and Region The holiday schedule data table simplifies configuration and reduces the potential for errors. This table allows users to complete a row to determine if that day is honored as a holiday. This example uses 23 LOBs with 17 annual holidays. You must update 17 campaign schedules for 23 campaigns as those schedules can't contain a relative date. For example, don't use the third Thursday of the month to indicate that Thanksgiving falls on the third Thursday of November as it may not fall on that day every year. • Each LOB has its own row. • Holidays are in columns. • Open or closed for each holiday (column) represented as True (open)/False (closed). System Dispositions Email Notifications for Dispositions Instant Message Notification for Dispositions Agents set the status or result of an interaction using dispositions and those dispositions appear in reports. A characteristic of dispositions is the ability to define them as open or closed. A closed disposition is for individual interactions, such as phone calls, and resolve the interaction. Agents typically set open dispositions for ongoing interactions, such as those by text or email. System and custom dispositions are available: l System Dispositions - Five9 provides these dispositions to help improve the reporting results of your campaigns. You cannot remove or add system dispositions, but you can modify some parameters. l Custom Dispositions - Admins create this disposition type for agents to assign to interactions. You can add, change, and remove custom dispositions. For example, you may configure a disposition so that busy numbers are redialed at five-minute intervals for up to ten times. For outbound campaigns, you can reset dispositions for numbers that have already been dialed. When deciding on dispositions for outbound campaigns, consider these categories: l Successful Calls (sale, lead, application taken, appointment set) l Negative Calls (not interested, hung up, add to DNC List) l Unknown Result (call

Dispositions Disposition Types 188 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Call Disposition Redial Number You can specify the redial time by selecting Use redial timer and entering the time to wait before trying the number again. This option also allows you to enable Allow agents to change reactivation time. The dialer attempts to dial the number as soon as possible, after that time, stopping somewhere in the call list to place the call, and then starting where it left off. You can also specify the maximum number if agents consecutively select this disposition multiple times. l Redial number after duration: Specify the days, hours, and minutes to redial this number. The dialer redials the number as soon as possible after the specified time. l Number of redial attempts: If agents consecutively set this disposition multiple times, this is the maximum number of redials the dialer attempts. l Allow agents to change redial time: In the Five9 Agent application, the disposition displays an additional menu to select a redial

possible after the specified time. l Number of redial attempts: If agents consecutively set this disposition multiple times, this is the maximum number of redials the dialer attempts. l Allow agents to change redial time: In the Five9 Agent application, the disposition displays an additional menu to select a redial time. The time configured in the redial timer setting is also shown to agents as the default option for this disposition. When an agent specifies a redial time, the phone number is redialed by the campaign at the designated time and the call is delivered to any available agent that is qualified for the campaign. Dispositions Disposition Types 189 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide This feature is useful for outbound customers whose agents work in shifts, such as when agents in the morning shift need to schedule campaign-related callbacks for agents in the evening shift. Profile and disposition counters apply to individual numbers in a record, not to the entire record. The profile and disposition counters restrict dialing to individual numbers within a record, rather than to the entire record. When using redial dispositions, consider these points: l Numbers without a redial timer are considered for dialing by a campaign

to individual numbers in a record, not to the entire record. The profile and disposition counters restrict dialing to individual numbers within a record, rather than to the entire record. When using redial dispositions, consider these points: l Numbers without a redial timer are considered for dialing by a campaign on next cycle through the list. l Numbers with a redial timer is dialed again after the time specified. l The dialer does not dial numbers with redial timers set when going through the list again. It only calls the number at the set time. l If a number receives the same redial disposition consecutively, the dialer stops attempts when the number of attempts is reached. l If a redial timer is set, the dialer does not call alternate phone numbers on the contact record until redialing the first number. l If no redial timer is set, the dialer begins calling the contact record's alternate phone numbers on its first pass of the list. l If Allow agents to change redial time is selected, the redial timer set by agents works in the same way and follows the same rules as the redial timer set by administrators. Redial without redial

calling the contact record's alternate phone numbers on its first pass of the list. l If Allow agents to change redial time is selected, the redial timer set by agents works in the same way and follows the same rules as the redial timer set by administrators. Redial without redial timer: the campaign starts at 10:00AM; records are dialed consecutively. 1 At 10:10AM, the campaign dials a number that is assigned to a Redial Number disposition without a redial timer set. 2 By 2:00PM, the campaign has called all records in the list. This cycle of dialing took 4 hours. 3 By 2:30PM, the campaign reaches the number again that was assigned a disposition with a Redial Number disposition: the campaign attempts to dial the number again 4 hours 20 minutes after the first attempt. Example Dispositions Custom Dispositions 193 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide FCC Compliance FCC regulations require that the percentage of dropped calls from all outbound campaigns fall within specified guidelines. The maximum percentage allowed for call abandonment is 3% for each campaign every 30 days. However, you should refer to the FCC regulations for requirements and call abandonment rate calculation to ensure that you have up-to-date information. Five9 has modified the calculation for the dropped call percentage to ensure that custom dispositions are not included in this calculation. Agents may use the No Human Contact disposition when they are connected to an object other than a person. Because the FCC calculation for abandoned calls excludes calls connected to non-live parties, using the No Human Contact disposition for reasons

Because the FCC calculation for abandoned calls excludes calls connected to non-live parties, using the No Human Contact disposition for reasons other than not connecting to live parties increases the dropped call percentage and Dialer Drop Call % rates (abandoned call rates). Configuring Custom Dispositions By default, after a call is assigned a final disposition, the phone number is not dialed again by that campaign, even if that number appears in another list. By setting flags, you can adjust this behavior and/or extend the functionality. These options currently work only with automated dialing by outbound campaigns - such as, Power, Predictive, or Progressive dialing modes. Preview dialing, manual calls, and inbound calls are not supported, and the prompt or IVR script will not play. The name of a disposition can contain up to 255 characters. l Description: Statement or purpose that identifies the disposition. l Agent must confirm choice of disposition: Requires that agents confirm the selection of this disposition. l Agent must complete worksheet: For campaigns that contain worksheets, requires that agents complete a worksheet before they can select this disposition. l No human contact (automated contact only): Indicates that no contact occurred with a person during the call. Because custom dispositions for No Human Contact or Abandoned Calls can affect FCC compliance, they are excluded from the abandoned call percentage calculation. The options are similar to those available in the Dialing Options tab of outbound campaign properties for answering machine detection: l Action on disposition selection: You can use the drop-down list to select one of the following options: o Do not leave message: No further action. o Play prompt: Switches the call to a message prompt line to allow the agent to disconnect from the call. message: No further action. o Play prompt: Switches the call to a message prompt line to allow the agent to disconnect from the call. The message plays after detecting two Dispositions System Dispositions 197 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide seconds of silence or when set by the Max Answering Machine Greeting Time option. You can only configure one message prompt per disposition. The prompt is played either after a two second silence is detected (for example, after the tone, please leave a message... beep) or after the configured Max Answering Machine Greeting Time. One prompt can be configured per disposition. o Play IVR script (advanced): Agents who are connected to an answering machine or voicemail box can disconnect from a call but leave a message playing for an answering machine. The IVR script plays after a two-second silence is detected (for example, after the tone, please leave a message... beep) or after the configured Max Answering Machine Greeting Time. The default Maximum Answering Machine Greeting Time is 5 seconds. You can use branching logic or dynamic Text-to-Speech when leaving a message. For example, to configure an IVR script that plays a personalized message from the agent assigned to the call, you can configure a Case module, with the Agent.user_name variable and connect the branches to one Play module for each agent. Another example would be to leave a message with dynamic Text-to-Speech, which can play information such as an account balance to a client. dispositions have the same options and properties as the custom dispositions, but some options and properties cannot be changed. You cannot create, delete, or rename system dispositions. You can configure different types (Redial, Add to DNC, and so on) for many system dispositions. Other options, such as timers, can be enabled for all system dispositions. Events Subscription Service (ESS) Events Subscription 208 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Events Subscription Service (ESS) Events Subscription Event Subscription Requirements Managing Subscriptions Configuring Subscriptions Creating an Event Subscription Events Subscription Application Access Retry Logic for HTTP Response Codes Event Subscriptions (ESS) Page Permissions Five9 Event Subscription requires you to obtain a license from Five9. When enabled, it is accessible from Five9 Plus Admin Web Console. For more information, contact your Five9 representative. Events Subscription Event Subscription provides access to Five9 platform events using a push mechanism by configuring one or more subscriptions. A subscription is a registration for one or more events of interest within a given event group for a specific destination address. Once a subscription is created and activated you are notified about subscribed Five9 events as soon as they occur. You continue to receive events if the subscription exists and remains active. Within a single subscription, you may only add events from a single event group. There are four event groups for which Five9 platform

created and activated you are notified about subscribed Five9 events as soon as they occur. You continue to receive events if the subscription exists and remains active. Within a single subscription, you may only add events from a single event group. There are four event groups for which Five9 platform events are available using event subscription. These event groups include: Events Subscription Service (ESS) Event Subscription Requirements 209 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide l Interaction Events: Events related to voice chat email interactions such as Call disposition, call connected, call parked, and so on. l Agent Events: Events related to agent states such as ready state, on preview, logout, and so on. l User Events: Events such as user locked out, login attempted, user password changed, and so on. l Configuration Change Events: Events related to Five9 domain critical resources such as add/remove/delete of skills, users, campaigns, dispositions, and so on. For a complete list of events supported within an event group, please refer to the events schema. Note: Five9 IP Addresses for Callback API Integration used by Event Subscription Service are listed in the Five9 Technical Requirements document: Five9 IP Addresses for Callback API Integration. on. For a complete list of events supported within an event group, please refer to the events schema. Note: Five9 IP Addresses for Callback API Integration used by Event Subscription Service are listed in the Five9 Technical Requirements document: Five9 IP Addresses for Callback API Integration. Event Subscription Requirements l Webhook delivery only supports HTTP delivery method. No Publish/Subscribe- based delivery method is offered. l Events are published based on the Five9 event schema definition. Event payload is fixed and is only available in JSON format. Fields selected at the event level are automatically added to the event payload. l Event subscription does not guarantee the delivery of events in the same order as the expected call flow sequence. This is due to the fact that the event repository does not guarantee the availability of events in a specified order. l Event subscription does not distinguish duplicate events being present in the event repository and as result if duplicate events are offered for processing into Event Subscription, then they will be processed and delivered. The entity receiving the delivery of any event is responsible for managing and filtering out duplicates, if necessary. l Customer group call attached variables are available

in the event repository and as result if duplicate events are offered for processing into Event Subscription, then they will be processed and delivered. The entity receiving the delivery of any event is responsible for managing and filtering out duplicates, if necessary. l Customer group call attached variables are available only on the “Dispositioned” interaction event. l Each of the configuration change event has a current and previous structure. Please note that CampaignChangeEvent uses the campaign as the label for the current structure. Events Subscription Service (ESS) Managing Subscriptions 210 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Managing Subscriptions The initial state of a newly created subscription is CREATED. Once started, the subscription moves to the Active state. Stopping an Active subscription moves it to the STOPPED state. A subscription can be updated only when it is in Active or Inactive states. Configuring Subscriptions Event subscriptions are configured using Five9 Administrator Console UI. Retry Logic for HTTP Response Codes The event subscription feature has built-in retry logic for valid HTTP response codes received from the subscriber application. Three retry attempts are performed in Note Events Subscription Service (ESS) Event Subscriptions (ESS) Page Permissions 216 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide addition to the original attempt. The retry logic interval varies based on the error codes received. The error codes and retry attempts are described in the table below. N/A 400 Bad Request 300 600 1200 401 Unauthorized No retries No retries No retries 404 Resource Not Found No retries No retries No retries 429 Retry - After header is not present 300 600 1200 429 Retry - After header is present Retry - After value Retry - After value Retry - After value 4XX excluding 400, 401, 404, 429 300 600 1200 500 10 No retry No retry 5XX 10 25 125 Note: Five9 abandons interactions if an event isn't received within the set number of attempts. File Destinations Configure FTP/SFTP/FTPS Settings 222 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Configure FTP/SFTP/FTPS Settings This section describes how to configure the default FTP settings to transfer call recordings and reports from the Five9 VCC server to your FTP server. In addition to these default settings, you can also configure specific settings for each campaign. Campaign and disposition settings override default settings. Depending on your business requirements, you can choose between FTP, SFTP, or FTPS. FTP is adequate if the path to the storage location for the recordings is already encrypted, such as when the location is at your site and you have implemented a VPN. Interaction Settings Domain Settings 233 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Task-to-Agent Distribution When tasks are in the skill waiting for assignment, these settings place priority on agent skills so that the interaction gets routed to an agent skilled in that issue. Order of Agent Skill Levels This is the default option. Agent skills and skill levels are given for each skill assigned to an agent. Skill level represents the agent's proficiency at the assigned skill and is similar to priority, with level = 1 being the highest priority. You select their skill level when assigning skills to agents. The skill level is the agent's proficiency at that skill. Skill level is similar to priority, where the lower the number, the higher their proficiency. Task distribution allows you to assign tasks to agents by skill priority. Skill priority determines the order that skills are

when assigning skills to agents. The skill level is the agent's proficiency at that skill. Skill level is similar to priority, where the lower the number, the higher their proficiency. Task distribution allows you to assign tasks to agents by skill priority. Skill priority determines the order that skills are listed in the agent's user properties (see, User Skills). Admin Console routes interactions to the next available agent with the highest skill priority. These criteria distribute tasks in this order: Call # Skill, Skill Level Order Task Priority Waiting Time Delivery Order 1 Sales, 1 1 70 10:00 1 2 Sales, 1 1 70 9:00 3 3 Support, 2 2 70 8:00 5 4 Support, 2 2 60 7:00 6 5 Billing, 1 3 70 6:00 2 6 Billing, 1 3 60 5:00 4 1 Skill, Skill Level: Determines agent routing when multiple skills are waiting for the same skill level to consecutively distribute tasks, for example, Sales - Skill Level_1, Support - Skill Level_1, ...Skill_N - Skill Level_1. Agent skill level distribution is in ascending order, routing Call #1, waiting the longest for the highest skill level, to the first available agent with the highest skill priority. 2 Skill

those interactions. This distribution eliminates consecutive distribution associated with alternate distribution algorithms. a skill to interrupt the preview for an agent with that skill. Graceful Agent State Transition (GAST) This global setting applies to outbound campaigns running in predictive, power, or progressive mode that are used in Five9 agent-facing applications. GAST allows you to define the duration an agent can take to transition from the Not Ready to the Ready state. In this time, agents don't receive manual calls or callbacks and manual calls aren't automatically answered. Enable the check-box and set the transition delay time in minutes and seconds. Speed of Answer Agent Productivity Exceptions Interaction Settings Interactions Settings 238 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Speed of Answer You can define speed of answer settings and also determine whether to include queue callback wait times in your Service Level/Speed of Answer (SL/SOA) calculations. Speed of Answer Threshold (mm:ss) This threshold value determines the service level for a call. If you want calls to answer within 30 seconds, set the threshold value to 30. The default value is five seconds. For inbound calls, the speed of answer is the interval between the call entering an ACD queue

Threshold (mm:ss) This threshold value determines the service level for a call. If you want calls to answer within 30 seconds, set the threshold value to 30. The default value is five seconds. For inbound calls, the speed of answer is the interval between the call entering an ACD queue and connecting to an agent. Service level is measured by comparing the SOA value to the threshold value. Service level is boolean and set as follows: l 1: SOA <= SOAthreshold; the agent answered the call in time. l 0: SOA > SOAthreshold; the agent don't answer the call before the threshold. Calls disconnected while in the queue for less than the threshold value are excluded. Speed of Answer Minimum Time (mm:ss) Calls shorter than this setting, such as abandoned calls and wrong numbers, are excluded from statistics. This parameter isn't used in outbound campaigns because Interaction Settings Interactions Settings 239 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide these campaigns don't use the ACD. The default value is five seconds. Include Queue Callback Wait Time in SL/SOA Calculation Enable this option to show SL calculations in Five9 reports and Supervisor Plus. This option includes the waiting time for queue callbacks. This option

239 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide these campaigns don't use the ACD. The default value is five seconds. Include Queue Callback Wait Time in SL/SOA Calculation Enable this option to show SL calculations in Five9 reports and Supervisor Plus. This option includes the waiting time for queue callbacks. This option is disabled by default. Service Level Calculation Examples This section describes how service level is calculated in different scenarios. For inbound examples, the speed of answer and the minimum call length are set. For outbound calls, the speed to answer is set. In all cases, statistics are calculated for one hour, for example: 1:00– 1:59 PM. Abandoned calls are excluded from calculations. Statistics are specific to either inbound or outbound calls. Only answered calls that involve talk time are included in statistics. Inbound Queues Speed of answer for the queue measures how fast the agent answers the call. This formula calculates the percentage of calls in a queue that met the service level because they were answered before the speed of answer threshold. l 120 calls in the inbound queue. l 20 calls were abandoned before the five-second minimum duration. l 120 - 20 = 100 calls in the queue

calculates the percentage of calls in a queue that met the service level because they were answered before the speed of answer threshold. l 120 calls in the inbound queue. l 20 calls were abandoned before the five-second minimum duration. l 120 - 20 = 100 calls in the queue for longer than five seconds count towards the service level agreement. l 50 calls were answered in fewer than 15 seconds. Interaction Settings Interactions Settings 240 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Inbound Talk Time Speed of answer for talk time measures how fast the agent handles the call to resolve the customer's problem (was talk time shorter or greater than minimum time?). This formula calculates the percentage of calls that meet the service level requirements of answered within the specified speed of answer and lasted longer than the minimum set call duration. l 120 calls in the queue. l 20 calls considered abandoned because their duration was shorter than the five- second set minimum. l 120- 20 = 100 calls in the queue count towards the service level agreement if answered before the speed of answer threshold. l 80 calls answered before the speed of answer threshold. calls considered abandoned because their duration was shorter than the five- second set minimum. l 120- 20 = 100 calls in the queue count towards the service level agreement if answered before the speed of answer threshold. l 80 calls answered before the speed of answer threshold. Cold Transfers A cold transfer is where the current agent just dials the next agent or party and then disconnects from the call. The call may end with multiple scenarios, such as voicemail, busy, or no answer. You can globally specify the waiting time allowed and the action to be taken when the timer expires, the transfer didn't connect, or for any other no- answer event. You can also allow agents to override the cold-transfer call settings.. Or you can enable agents to adjust these settings for each call. Changes override the agent settings and take effect at their next login. Assigning User Permissions Within the Administrator Console, permissions and permission sets allow you to control the functions or features users can perform. Each permission gives access to a function within an application (or multiple applications). A Permission Set is a group of permissions that represent a function for a user (may represent a type of user). By grouping permissions into sets, you can easily update the users with the complete set of permissions.

permission gives access to a function within an application (or multiple applications). A Permission Set is a group of permissions that represent a function for a user (may represent a type of user). By grouping permissions into sets, you can easily update the users with the complete set of permissions. When permissions are added or removed from a permission set, all associated users' permissions are updated. The use of permission sets is optional; however, it is recommended. The benefits of using permission sets include: l Changing the permission set will update all associated users l A user may be associated to one or more permission sets l A user may have both individual permissions and permission sets, this is useful if you need to give a manager one extra permission than they currently have via their permission sets. Permissions and Permission Sets VCC Legacy Permissions without API 256 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide A default permission set, Default user management access, provides limited permissions as a quick starting point for administrative access without enabling full access to all user management functions. • Administrator’s Guide A default permission set, Default user management access, provides limited permissions as a quick starting point for administrative access without enabling full access to all user management functions. VCC Legacy Permissions without API When defining a permission set, before any permissions are included in the set, the administrator decides on the type of permissions to include, either fine grain permissions or existing legacy (VCC) permissions. The two types of permissions cannot be mixed in the same permission set. There are specific API-based legacy permissions that can be included in permission sets. These sets should then not be assigned to application only user types. There are specific API-based legacy permissions that should NOT be included in permission sets. When adding users to a permission set that includes legacy (VCC) permissions, users that are associated with a user profile cannot be added. Upon viewing the user's details and permissions tab, the permissions associated with the user through the permission sets (which may or may not be included in a circle) cannot be removed from the user. Permissions and Permission Sets Examples of Permission Sets 258 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Examples of Permission Sets You create permission sets for various reasons, for example to: l Streamline and standardize permission assignments for administrators with common duties and capabilities, such as campaign management. l Represent areas of function, like Internal Messages (chats with other agents/supervisors). l Function for all types of user needs, like a Tier 1 Agent answering phone calls. l Have probational action capabilities. Like, being able to record calls and perform Test calls may be permissions you only want users (for example, new hire employees) to have for a period of time. It may be useful to create permission sets of all user types. For example, one user might be a Tier 1 agent who can work with Internal Messages, while also in a probation time period. However, a newly hired Tier 1 agent may not yet able to do internal messaging while shadowing

be useful to create permission sets of all user types. For example, one user might be a Tier 1 agent who can work with Internal Messages, while also in a probation time period. However, a newly hired Tier 1 agent may not yet able to do internal messaging while shadowing and having calls monitored. You could associate the user to Tier 1 and Probational action permission sets. Working With Permission Sets Navigate the list of permission sets and create new sets on the Permission Sets page (Manage Users > Permission Sets). and update permission sets. l Associating users to permission sets. The changed permissions do not take immediate effect within Administrator Console regardless of modifications to user permissions. Associating Users to Permission Sets When you have permission sets, you can associate them with users by navigating to Permission Sets (Manage Users > Permission Sets). On the permission set Details page, select the Users tab. Use the Add button and select users to add to the permission set. Use the trash icon to remove users from a permission set. The list of users in the permission set immediately updates. You must remove them from the permission set to disable their access to that action. Number Types A number is a telephone number assigned to your domain in the E.164 format. These are the supported number types: l DID (Direct Inward Dial): Number to assign to an agent for outside calls from customers (see User Personal Information). l IDID (International DID): Number to assign an agent outside of the United States; includes the country code. l TFN (Toll Free Number): Number without fees. l ITFS (International Toll-Free Service/Number): Number without fees for use outside of the United States; includes the country code. l Loopback: Internal Five9 numbers for internal call routing. l UIFN: Universal International Freephone Number. Only applicable to calls originating from and terminating within the US. l SMS Enabled: Numbers provisioned for SMS. l Provider: The entity that provided the number. Audio files are used also for voicemail greetings, but they are uploaded directly to the User or Skill properties window. Enabling Prompts in the Administrator Console Prompts are configured in the Java VCC application by default and must be enabled for migration to the Administrator Console. Warning: Existing prompts are migrated to the cloud, or Five9 Administrator Console, as WAV files. Nuance® voices are no longer supported. For more information, see Prompts Page Permissions Prompts Audio Prompts Defined 273 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Audio Prompts Defined A voice prompt is an audio file used in IVR scripts to play a greeting or give callers instructions or information, for example: Thank you for calling Acme Company. Please hold for the next available agent or Please press 1 for Technical Support or 2 for Sales. Optionally, the files may contain captions. Audio files require this format: WAV audio, ITU G.711 mu-law, mono 8000 Hz. In some applications, the format may be listed as CCITT u-Law, 8.000 kHz, 8 bit, Mono, 7 kb/sec. Create a prompt by using one of these methods: l Use a professional voice-over service. Five9 recommends this option for a caller-friendly experience in your IVR. l Use the built-in Text-to-Speech (TTS) engine. Import audio files into the Prompts folder in the Administrator Console application. An imported

Mono, 7 kb/sec. Create a prompt by using one of these methods: l Use a professional voice-over service. Five9 recommends this option for a caller-friendly experience in your IVR. l Use the built-in Text-to-Speech (TTS) engine. Import audio files into the Prompts folder in the Administrator Console application. An imported prompt can be used in multiple inbound campaigns. Prompts can be played sequentially by linking multiple Play modules in the IVR. Prompts can be edited. Users can be assigned to multiple skills and campaigns can have multiple skills. Each skill has attributes that represent the logical teams to route interactions to. Use the Create button to create new skills. The listing page will indicate when you have reached the maximum number of skills, and prevent you from creating additional skills. Skill Level The skill level determines the agent’s priority in receiving calls sent to that skill. Level one is the highest priority. Agents with higher ranking receives calls first. After an admin updates an agent’s skills in VCC Admin, the agent must log out, clear the cache, and log back in to see the updates. When an agent logs in, their Five9 permissions, skills, and other relevant data are stored in the browser cache. When they log out and log back in later, the application uses this cached data to quickly restore the previous session and load the last agent profile settings. If there have been changes to the agent's skills or permissions on the backend, it is recommended that they clear their cache to start with a fresh session and see the updates on their next login. If permitted by your IT policies, you can configure the browser to automatically clear the cache when closed, making sure it is empty for each new login. Tag Management Using Tags 308 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Tags may only be string-type values and can be structured flatly, or into layered folders as represented below. Engineering Support Sales l West o Bay Area l Central o Wisconsin l East o Atlanta Using Tags Tags can be associated to users to define an organizational grouping, such as Midwest, or associated to resources, such as campaigns, skills, or profiles. Tags are designed to aid you in organizing data that can be filtered and also restricting data so that only users with matching tags can manage the resources. Additionally, users may be associated with tags for security restrictions. This association is done in the form of Permission Tags in the Users detail page, Permissions tab. This administration requires additional user-tags permissions. Using Tags for Quick Search Tags enable quick search with objects that have tag associations by simply filtering for those tags. Example Tag Management Creating Tags 309 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Using Tags for Permission Restriction When viewing the User Details Permissions tab, there is an indication of which tags are in place (lower portion of this page), the permission set that is associated

by simply filtering for those tags. Example Tag Management Creating Tags 309 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Using Tags for Permission Restriction When viewing the User Details Permissions tab, there is an indication of which tags are in place (lower portion of this page), the permission set that is associated to the user, and the individual permissions for which these tags apply. Only objects with matching tags enable users to perform that permission. For permission sets that enforce tag matching, you may see a incomplete listing of those permissions due to tag restrictions. In this case, you see a indication in the list header telling you why the list is partial. Note: Only permission sets, not individual permissions, enforce tag matching. An object that has no tag restrictions is fully available, even for restricted users. Also, a user without any tag restrictions is never restricted. Upload Rules 332 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide 7 Select a pre-defined file destination from the drop-down. See File Destinations. 8 Select a delivery type. Individual Recordings – Entire Call: The entire interaction is recorded in individual segments. Individual Recordings – Matching Filter: Portions of your interaction match your filters in individual segments. Combined Recording – Matching Filter: Portions of your interaction match your filters in a single file. Combined Recording – For the Call: The entire call is exported in a single file. Combined Recording – Based on Agents: When filter criteria match at least one recorded call segment, all recorded segments are exported and grouped by the Recording.agent variable. Although this behavior is identical to that of Combined Recording – Per Call, it applies to all calls that

in a single file. Combined Recording – Based on Agents: When filter criteria match at least one recorded call segment, all recorded segments are exported and grouped by the Recording.agent variable. Although this behavior is identical to that of Combined Recording – Per Call, it applies to all calls that have been transferred between agents. 9 Select a pre-defined file name pattern. Five9 Nightly User Sync During nightly syncs, the system looks for modified or new users and examines their VCC permissions. Select a user or select Edit to view their details. The General tab lists basic user attributes. You must have permissions to edit user attributes. The Details pane shows the status of the user ("Active" or "Inactive") and if the user is associated with a User Profile. their most recent login activity is shown, including: date and time, device operating system and browser, and IP address. User Security 351 Administrator Console • Administrator’s Guide Identity Migration Status This section shows the user's identity migration status. For more information about user identity migration, see Managing Identity Migration. The possible user migration statuses are: l Fit -- The user is eligible to migrate. l Unfit -- The user requires intervention from the admin before migration. For example, they may first need to change their password to align with security policies, or they might have an invalid email address or user name to resolve. l Excluded -- A user may have a programmatic or manual exclusion. For example, a user with API permissions will be automatically excluded. Optionally, you may assign the excluded status to a user that you do not want to migrate but would otherwise be considered fit for migration. l Scheduled -- The user is assigned to a migration batch. l In progress -- The user has authenticated once. l Migrated -- The user migration is complete. For more information about user identity migration eligibility, see Eligible Users. Federation ID Enter the Federation ID for this user,

Under Password Change, select one of the options described below. Note: Upon logging into the Admin Console, a message appears stating, "Your password has expired. You must log in again and reset your password on the main portal." A race condition is preventing all systems from being updated for the password reset. You may be prompted to reset your password again. Omni Group 15 Basic Configuration • Administrator’s Guide About the Virtual Contact Center Administrator Application This information describes how to use the Five9 Virtual Contact Center (VCC) Administrator application to configure and manage your contact center domain. The VCC is cloud-based software provided as a service for creating and managing outbound and inbound contact center operations: l In outbound campaigns, the automatic dialer can make multiple simultaneous calls. The dialer can skip busy signals, answering and fax machines, and no answer calls. Agents process calls answered only by a live person. About the Virtual Contact Center Administrator Application Logging In to Five9 16 Basic Configuration • Administrator’s Guide l In inbound campaigns, callers dial directly

multiple simultaneous calls. The dialer can skip busy signals, answering and fax machines, and no answer calls. Agents process calls answered only by a live person. About the Virtual Contact Center Administrator Application Logging In to Five9 16 Basic Configuration • Administrator’s Guide l In inbound campaigns, callers dial directly to the VCC which automatically routes calls to agents based the campaign settings, such as skills and status. The applications correspond to the user roles: l Administrators configure and manage your Five9 contact center. l Supervisors monitor and manage agents and campaigns, and view real-time statistics for contact center operations. l Agents use the Internet to connect to the VCC from anywhere in the world so that they can process calls based on the rules that you define. l Dashboards and Reports provides tools to analyze information about contact center, campaign, and agent performance. Logging In to Five9 To log into your Five9 account, navigate to https://login.five9.com and enter your credentials. Temporarily Blocking User Accounts To prevent unauthorized access, users are blocked from accessing applications after several failed authentication attempts as follows: l A user account is blocked for 15 minutes after five failed authentication attempts within one hour. l When a user's password is changed, that user account is typically unlocked within one minute. l Lockout information is not shared between the Digital Channels Administrator and VCC Administrator applications. For example, a user may be locked out of the VCC Administrator application but not locked out of the Digital Channels Administrator application. l A user that is locked out of the Digital Channels Administrator application may still access digital channel reporting using VCC social reports.
